Title: Animals domesticated
Description: Not horses. Maybe dogs and oxen?

Title: Fishing nets
Description: Made out of linen.

Title: Weight scales
Description: For measurement

Title: Copper
Description: First obtained from ore

Title: Bronze
Description: Bronze first smelted.

Title: River boats
Description: First used on the Nile.

Title: Writing
Description: Oldest surviving example of writing on parchment.

Title: Nations
Description: Egypt

Title: Candles
Description: Made out of animal fat.

Title: Stone monuments
Description: Oldest surviving stone monuments

Title: Horses
Description: First domesticated horses

Title: Number system
Description: Base 60

Title: Fermentation
Description: According to Wikipedia, fermentation was used in 6000 BCE in China.

Title: Code of Laws
Description: First surviving law code established

Title: Recorded medicine
Description: First surviving account of medical remedies: Eber’s Papyrus

Title: Phonetic alphabet
Description: Phonecian alphabet

Title: Monotheism
Description: First in Egypt

Title: Dyes
Description: Dyes resistant to sun and water invented.

Title: Sea navigation
Description: Phonecians

Title: Steel
Description: Iron Age begins

Title: Architectural arches
Description: Etruscans

Title: Currency (Coins)
Description: Lydian government issued pieces of gold w/ standard weight

Title: Water as element
Description: Water as an element theorized

Title: Irrational numbers
Description: Unit isoceles right triangle with hypotenuse sqrt(1)

Title: Ocean navigation
Description: Early exploration of the Atlantic ocean

Title: Abacus
Description: Earliest: Greece

Title: Venus named
Description: I guess it’s significant that the evening star and morning star were identified.

Title: Dream interpretation
Description: Rational interpretation of dreams theorized

Title: Rationalism
Description: Everything has a non-divine cause.

Title: Atoms
Description: Early atoms theorized (the world is made of indivisible particles)

Title: Epilepsy
Description: Epilepsy the disease discovered. Hippocrates thought disease was due to a misbalance between the four humors: blood, phlegm, bile, black bile.

Title: Paved roads
Description: Appian Way

Title: Lighthouses
Description: Lighthouse of Alexandria (at Pharos)

Title: Lever mathematics
Description: Also estimated the value of pi to 3.142

Title: Standardized years
Description: Formerly "the seventh year of King X"

Title: Parchment
Description: Previously papyrus, now animal skin.

Title: Better star maps
Description: Including magnitudes (brightnesses), included 1000 stars

Title: Glass blowing
Description: Previously glass making was done by hand

Title: Water wheels
Description: First written mention, likely invented earlier. According to wikipedia, MUCH earlier.

Title: Julian calendar
Description: Julian calendar (including leap year) adopted

Title: Climactic zones
Description: first suggested

Title: Recorded medicinal plants
Description: Described 600 plants, 1000 drugs.

Title: Rudimentary steam engine
Description: Worked like a modern lawn sprinkler, had no bearing on society

Title: Paper
Description: Took 1000 years to reach Europe

Title: Geocentric universe
Description: Remained canon for 14 centuries

Title: Spinal cord
Description: Cut animals’ spines to see resulting paralysis

Title: Algebra
Description: Fractions can be treated as numbers.

Title: Tea
Description: Reduced infection since it required water to be boiled

Title: Recorded alchemy
Description: Unclear why this matters.

Title: Metal stirrups
Description: More stability for the rider, less chance to be thrown off horse in battle

Title: Wheelbarrows
Description: Potentially much earlier than 400.

Title: Architectural domes
Description: Hagia Sophia

Title: Silk in Europe
Description: Constantinople began silk production

Title: Moldboard plows
Description: A plow with a vertical knife-blade that cut deep into the earth. Useful for damp, moist ground, led to increase in carrying capacity. Aka Turnplow

Title: Greek fire
Description: A napalm like weapon for naval battle

Title: Porcelain
Description: Eventually came to Europe, known as “China” and replaced wood dishes

Title: Acetic acid
Description: Found accidentally, while trying to find an alchemic elixir of life

Title: Iron horseshoes
Description: (Outside of Asimov: Frankish King Childeric in 550)

Title: Zero
Description: Around 500 zero as a symbol was invented in India.  First used in positional notation

Title: Coffee
Description: Muslims didn’t know about tea, couldn’t drink alcohol, so needed some water that was treated.

Title: Arctic circle
Description: First crossing into the arctic circle

Title: Iceland settled
Description: Europe’s first expansion to new land overseas. Iceland first discovered around 550 by Brendan, an Irishman

Title: Horse collars
Description: Allowed horses to pull by their shoulders not their windpipe, increasing pulling capacity by 5x

Title: Optics
Description: Human vision understood and vision correcting lenses invented. Foundation of the field of optics

Title: Crossbows
Description: First mechanized handheld weapon. Range of 300m, penetrated chainmail

Title: New star
Description: Creation of new star witnessed. Went unnoticed in Europe

Title: Gunpowder
Description: Used by the Chinese in war mostly to scare the mongols (not efficient weapons)

Title: Forks (Europe)
Description: Originated in Byzantium, arrived in Venice. Replaced eating with fingers

Title: Flying buttresses
Description: St. Denis in 1137.

Title: Windmills (Europe)
Description: Actually invented around 700, brought to France from persia. Alternative power to water wheels

Title: Magnetic navigation
Description: Magnetic compasses first used for navigation. Thales of Greece discovered magnetixation of metal. Chinese discovered N-S orientation.

Title: Spitz bergen
Description: Extremely far north islands at 79 degrees N

Title: Arabic numerals (Europe)
Description: Popularized by Fibonacci, but existed in parallel with Roman numerals for 3 centuries

Title: Coal mining
Description: First mined in Newcastle. Important in England since land was being deforested.

Title: Rudders (Europe)
Description: Likely brought back from crusades. Widely used by ships of Hanseatic League

Title: Eyeglasses invented
Description: Invented in China around the same time. Only convex.

Title: Gunpowder (Europe)
Description: Perfected by Europeans to make it a serious weapon

Title: Planetary tables
Description: More accurate than Ptolemy's geocentric model

Title: Magnetic poles
Description: Poles discovered, magnetic compass improved. Proto-experimental science

Title: Mirrors
Description: Previously all glass was colored, but with clear glass, all it took was a backing metal surface

Title: Far east (Europe)
Description: Far east became a wonder-goal for European dreamers

Title: Spinning wheels
Description: Previously done by hand, spinning wheels made the process much easier

Title: Longbows
Description: Twice the range of a crossbow, far greater force. Big implications for war

Title: Sulfuric acid
Description: Far stronger than acetic acid

Title: Liquor distillation
Description: Much faster than waiting for natural fermentation. Villanova made Brandy

Title: Realistic comets
Description: First realistic depiction of a comet as seen by naked eye. Painted in "Adoration of the Magi"

Title: Canary islands (Europe)
Description: Originally discovered in 40 BCE by King of Mauritania

Title: Anatomy book
Description: After a ban, cadaver dissection became possible again

Title: Mechanical clocks
Description: Weight-powered, more accurate than water clock. Hourly chimes

Title: Cannons
Description: Primitive cannons used at siege of Metz

Title: Quarantine
Description: Venician policy to delay strangers from entering the city until a waiting period had passed (40 days)

Title: Indian ocean
Description: Led expedition to Red Sea, India, Ceylon, brought back ruler of Ceylon as prisoner

Title: Madeira settled
Description: Kicked off the European Age of Exploration

Title: Azores
Description: 1/3 of the way to America. Like Madeira, originally uninhabited, also still part of Portugal

Title: Perspective drawing
Description: Book published about how to draw in perspective

Title: Artillery
Description: Improved upon cannons. Artillery was good against city walls

Title: Arquebus
Description: First gun small enough to be fired by one person

Title: Concave lenses
Description: Previous lenses (convex) were only for farsighted people

Title: Movable type
Description: Proto-printing was done by Sumerians and Chinese

Title: Comet trajectory tracking
Description: Comets usually viewed with terror, now understood rationally.

Title: Cape of Good Hope
Description: Initially called Cape of Storms, renamed as Good Hope by John II who knew it would open trade routes with orient

Title: New world (Europe)
Description: Funding from Spain, first landing: Bahamas.

Title: Magnetic declination
Description: Saw declination of the compass compared to the stars

Title: Syphilis
Description: Breakout during siege of Naples by France. Named after the protagonist of a poem that had syphilis.

Title: India water (Europe)
Description: Lost 3/5 of crew to scurvy.

Title: America  (Europe)
Description: Realized they weren't in Asia

Title: Spring-powered watches
Description: Allowed much smaller, non-vertical clocks

Title: Pacific ocean (Europe)
Description: In search of asian wealth, crossed panama to get to the Pacific. Called it the "south sea".

Title: Florida
Description: First portion of USA to be settled by Europeans

Title: Mexico conquered
Description: 17: Landed on Yucatan, traces of Maya 19: landed and went to war

Title: Earth circumnavigated
Description: Didn't know Magellan died in Guam, not technically finishing

Title: Peru conquered
Description: Spain held it for 3 centuries

Title: Cubic equations
Description: Quadratic equations had been solved for a long time

Title: Comet tails
Description: Comet tails always point away from the sun. News to me! Also independently discovered by Peter Bennewitz

Title: Mississipi river (Europe)
Description: Commisioned by Charles V

Title: Amazon river (Europe)
Description: Actually went west to east, from Quito to Marajo

Title: Mathematics of heliocentricity
Description: Still kept the concentric circle constraint the Greeks proposed but greatly improved math.

Title: Illustrated anatomy book
Description: Published "Concerning the Structure of the Human Body" including illustrations of human anatomy

Title: Negative numbers
Description: First used to represent debt. Also negative integers, fractions, irrationals.

Title: Rational surgery
Description: Improved surgical techniques, eg. tying off arteries rather than burning.

Title: Trigonometric tables
Description: Built tables of angle ratios to make astronomy calculations easier

Title: Better planetary tables
Description: Used Copernicus' math to improve over previous planetary tables.

Title: Eustacian tubes
Description: Described tube going from ear to throat, as well as adrenal glands published a new anatomy book

Title: Northeastern passage
Description: First crossing through northeastern passage landed in Archangelsk (so not quite the whole way to asia). Improved Russia-English trade relations

Title: Vertebrate skeletons
Description: Similarities between vertebrate skeletons documented, noted that number of bones in limbs were often constant regardless of animal species. Foreshadowed evolution

Title: Mining book
Description: Basically founded Mineralogy. Also contributed: Theophrastus Bombastus von Hohenheim (best name ever?)

Title: Tobacco (Europe)
Description: Europeans learned about Tobacco from Native Americans. Nicotine named after Nicot, ambassador to Portugal who sent tobacco seeds to France.

Title: Scientific societies
Description: First scientific association for idea exchange “Academy of the Mysteries of Nature” was closed down by the inquisition shortly, but others formed later.

Title: Musket
Description: Arquebus was further refined into a Musket, first weapon to pierce armor. Armor penetrating meant armor was obsolete. Muskets remained principle small arms for 2 centuries

Title: Mercator projection
Description: Main feature of Mercator projection: movement in a fixed compass direction appears as a straight line on the map. The cover of the book showed Atlas holding the world on his shoulders, this is why books of maps are called atlases.

Title: Supernova (Europe)
Description: Observed the process over 485 days (until it became invisible). Notion of heavenly immutability destroyed.

Title: Greenland revisited
Description: Discovered Baffin Island, and second time around, Greenland rediscovered. All Vikings settlers had died or left. No viable NW passage path

Title: Comet distances
Description: Distance to comets proven to be far beyond previous notions. Greeks thought comets were atmospheric phenomenon (!), but Tycho saw no parallax in the comet’s trajectory, proving it was far.

Title: Drake Strait
Description: Discovered a passage around the southernmost tip of South America. Attempting to find Straight of Magellan, which weaves through South American continent (far south), Drake overshot and found an even more southern passage. Coming back around he got as far as SFBA. 60 years after Magellan this was only the second circumnavigation of the world.

Title: Time pendulums
Description: First inkling that pendulums might have good time-keeping properties. Most time keeping done via heart rate, dripping water, burning candle, etc. (Surprising, given mechanical watches previously invented)

Title: Siberia settled (Europe)
Description: Driven by fur trade, Russia expanded east. Timofievich conquered last Mongol kingdom named Sibir. Eventually paved the way to Russians in the Pacific.

Title: Gregorian calendar
Description: Pope mandated a calendar switch, causing holidays to be more aligned with seasons. A leap year every 4 years means a year is 365.25 days, but it’s actually 365.2422 days long. To avoid error new calendar introduced a new rule. Instead of 1/4, 97/100 had to be leap years. To adjust for the offset, 10 days were dropped on October 4, 1582. The next day was October 15.

Title: Hydrostatics
Description: Foundational experiment: pressure of liquid on surface depends on height of liquid and area of surface but not shape of vessel

Title: Positional notation
Description: Positional notation including decimals for tenths, hundredths etc columns. Greatly simplified calculations using fractions. Downside: infinitely repeating decimals (eg. 1/3)

Title: Falling motion
Description: Definitive proof that objects fall at same acceleration regardless of their mass. Confusions stemmed from air resistance. Also showed that force not necessary to keep object in perpetual motion. Credited with founding experimental science.

Title: Code breaking
Description: Early example of code breaking

Title: Stocking frame
Description: First knitting machine more efficient than by hand. Elizabeth I refused to grant a patent for fear of throwing hand knitters out of work. First example of technological unemployment.

Title: Microscope
Description: Janssen, a spectacle maker first stacked two convex lenses to amplify the magnification.

Title: Algebraic symbols
Description: Algebraic symbol system proposed, using x and y for variables

Title: Thermometer
Description: First quantification of temperature. Simple device consisting of a long glass tube with markings that drew water up into it. As water warmed, it crept higher into the tube.

Title: East indies settled
Description: Dutch expansion into Asia. Setup a factory at Palembang on Sumatra, starting the Dutch overseas empire

Title: PI accuracy
Description: Archimedes estimated to 3.142, but van Ceulen got it to 20 and then 35 decimal places.

Title: Chemistry book
Description: Described preparation of hydrochloride and sulfuric and nitric acid. Still Alchemy, but set stage for real chemistry.

Title: Magnetic earth
Description: Discovery that Earth itself is a large magnet. Did a series of magnet-related experiments like disproving that garlic destroys magnetism and diamonds produce it.

Title: Vein valves
Description: Discovery that veins have valves that prevent backflow. Galen’s doctrine was that blood was made in liver, carried to heart and pumped through arteries and veins. Fabrici found something else but didn’t dare to go against Galen

Title: English America
Description: Jamestown became first permanent English settlement in North America

Title: Telescope
Description: First telescope invented. Spectacle maker accidentally found that two lenses, one at a distance from another enabled him to see really far and upside-down.

Title: French America
Description: Quebec: first permanent French settlement in North America, Commissioned by Henry IV

Title: Elliptical orbits
Description: Discovery that planetary orbits aren’t circular but elliptical. Working under Tycho Brahe, Kepler found that his teacher’s data worked best for non-circular orbits with sun at one of the foci’s. Also developed Kepler’s laws.

Title: Milky Way
Description: Discovery that the Milky Way is full of stars. Galileo replicated Lippershey’s telescope and peered into the Milky Way, discerning many small stars.

Title: Moon mountains
Description: Discovery that the moon has mountains. Also with the help of his telescope, Galileo discerned dark spots on the moon t hat might have been seas. Ultimately it suggested that the moon wasn’t just a globe of light, but a world.

Title: Jupiter's four moons
Description: Discovery that Jupiter has 4 moons orbiting it. Another point against egocentrism.

Title: Venus phases
Description: Discovery that Venus has a full range of phases. The discovery strongly suggests heliocentric model.

Title: Sunspots
Description: Discovery of sunspots. Annoying to religious conservatives since the sun was supposed to be perfect.

Title: Nebulas
Description: Discovery of nebulas (specifically Andromeda)

Title: Logarithms
Description: Napier first produced a table of logarithms.

Title: Biological metabolism
Description: Beginning of the study of biological metabolism. Self-experimented while eating and drinking, found he lost more weight than the weight of his feces and urine.

Title: Baffin Bay
Description: Came as far as 78 deg N, within 800 miles of North Pole, concluding that there was no practical NW passage. Furthest north for 2.5 centuries.

Title: Tierra Del Fuego
Description: Sailed around the southern tip of Cape Horn, which is on a large island.

Title: Stagecoaches
Description: Apparently stagecoaches is a horse and carriage that follows a schedule, taking passengers between destinations for payment. (Wow, an early form of public transport)

Title: Scientific method
Description: New Organon published. Bacon laid out the foundation for the scientific method, going beyond logic. Formalized experimental science.

Title: Light refraction
Description: Mathematical model for light refraction. Well known that when a beam of light passes from air into water, it bends towards the vertical. Snel quantified it.

Title: Slide rules
Description: Predecessor to slide rules, which were actively used by scientists and engineers for 350 years to calculate logarithms. Only replaced by pocket calculators.

Title: Gas state
Description: Gas state of matter formulated. Greeks had four elements, and any vapor was a kind of air. Helmont suggested that like different solids and liquids, there can be different “airs”.

Title: Better planetary tables
Description: Greatly improved by Napier’s logarithms, which was the first application of the technique.

Title: Aurochs extinction
Description: Closest ancestor of cattle became extinct. Aurochs weren’t hunted deliberatey, just ran out of space due to domesticated cows.

Title: Blood circulation
Description: Circulatory system first understood. “Concerning motion of heart and blood” published, in which circulation is described: right ventricle => lungs => left ventricle => all over body => right ventricle

Title: Science religion debates
Description: Serious criticism of church worldview. Written in Italian (not Latin), “Dialog on the two chief world systems” was accessible to the public and created a huge stir. Copernicus-supporter was described favorably, Ptolemy-supporter laughed at. Pope forced Galileo to renounce his views.

Title: Shifting magnetic declination
Description: Discovered that magnetic north and geographic north aren’t the same, and that magnetic north shifts position over time.

Title: Cartesian geometry
Description: Represented points in 2D space as pairs of coordinates, with graphs of functions first illustrated. Algebraic and geometric solutions. Laid foundation for calculus.

Title: Fermat's last theorem
Description: Conjectured that no 3 positive integers a, b, c exist such that a^n + b^n = c^n (for n > 2). Only proven 350 years later.

Title: Cross hairs
Description: First cross hairs used in the center of an optical scope. A specific spot could be located and accurately centered at the crossing point of two lines, increasing precision of telescope

Title: Quinine
Description: Quinine as treatment for malaria in Europe. Incas used bark of cinchona tree, in which active ingredient quinine treats malaria. Allowed Europeans to remain in tropical climates.

Title: Mechanical calculators
Description: A series of wheels were connected in a clever way so when one rotation was made, the next wheel would turn. First patented in 1649 it was a commercial failure because it was too expensive.

Title: New Zealand and Tasmania
Description: Seeking a continent entirely in the Southern Hemisphere (predicted by Greeks), European explorers went south. Tasman discovered Indonesia, then Tasmania, then New Guinea and also South Island of New Zealand.

Title: Barometers
Description: Major mining problem of the time was that water wouldn’t lift more than 33 ft. To investigate, Galileo’s assistant investigated it, and invented barometer. Cool experiment to boot. Also observed changes in atmospheric pressure over time.

Title: Air pumps
Description: First practical air pump worked liked a water pump, but more airtight. Used to create vacuums, showed that  in a vacuum, sounds couldn’t be heard, flame can’t burn. Estimated air’s density.

Title: Air pressure altitude
Description: Air pressure was found to depend on altitude. Pascal was too sick to go himself, so sent his brother in law up a mountain, saw mercury column descend from 30” to 27”. Showed atmosphere would have finite height of ~100 mi

Title: Double star
Description: First double star observed. Middle star of the Big Dipper is actually two stars very close together.

Title: Biblical earth age
Description: Theologians decide earth created in 4004 BC. More specifically, 9am on October 26, 4004 BC (what time zone tho?)

Title: Moon features named
Description: Features of the moon first named. Published a map of the moon in “New Algamest” and named craters of the moon after famous astronomers: Tycho, Copernicus, Ptolemaeus, and Kepler.

Title: Lymphatic vessels
Description: Veins and arteries well known, but a third type of vessel resembling veins was found. These vessels had thinner walls, carried “lymph”, or watery parts of blood. Took back interstitial fluid from outside of cells.

Title: Probability
Description: Consulting with Pascal and Fermat, a certain gambler wanted to understand why he kept losing at dice. These greats formulated a mathematics for considering a large number of random events, unpredictable on their own, but in predictable in aggregate.

Title: Early pneumatics
Description: Demonstrated power of air pressure through experiments: fifty men struggled to pull a cylinder out of a vacuum. Teams of horses tried to separate two hemispheres sealed in a vacuum.

Title: Saturn's ring
Description: Build a large telescope (23ft long) with better lens grinding techniques, and were able to see Saturn’s rings, which eluded Galileo. Also saw Orion Nebula rather than a single star.

Title: Grandfather clocks
Description: An ordinary pendulum swings in the arc of a circle and doesn’t have a constant period (?). But a cycloid trajectory enables a constant period. The clock involved counterweights and a cycloid always pendulum and could tell time far better than its predecessor.

Title: Falling motion experiment
Description: Definitive experiment created a vacuum (mitigating air resistance) using an air pump and dropped feather and coin at the same time, and they fell at the same speed

Title: Red blood cells
Description: Red blood cells first seen in blood w/ microscope. Due to improvements in microscopes in 1650s, Swammerdam studied insects. Father of modern entomology (study of insects).

Title: Syrtis Major
Description: Dark triangular marking on Mars

Title: Capillaries
Description: Capillaries first seen under microscope. Previous unclear was how blood got from arteries to veins (to get back to heart). Harvey's theory suggested that there should be vessels, but they were too small to see.

Title: Static electricity
Description: First demonstration of static electricity at scale. Inspired by attractive forces from rubbing amber (elektron in Greek), Guericke built a sulfur globe that could be rotated to generate a lot of static electricity and then produce sparks.

Title: Scientific chemistry
Description: Definition of chemical elements. 2000 years after Aristotle's 4 elements, published "The Skeptical Chymist", changing the name alchemist => chemist.  Suggested defining elements as components that can't be converted into anything simpler.

Title: Acid-base balance
Description: Acid-base balance is necessary for health. Supplanted the 4 humor theory (bile, blood, phlegm, black bile) with acid-base balance. Suggested digestion was more chemical than mechanical.

Title: Boyle's law
Description: Experiments in compressing gas showed an inverse relationship between volume and pressure in gas.

Title: Royal Society
Description: The English Royal Society became the first scientific society, other nations modeled theirs after it. Legal charter.

Title: Jupiter's Red Spot
Description: It's so huge the whole Earth could fit inside.

Title: Cells
Description: Published Micrographia which outlined his work. Looked at structure of cork, saw dead cells. First use of the term "cell"

Title: Diffraction
Description: Saw light bending around objects. First inkling that light may have wave like properties.

Title: Planetary rotation
Description: All planets rotate around their own axes. Discovered that Mars has a period of 24h40m, Jupiter 9h56m.

Title: Prisms
Description: First observed light spectrum. Used a prism to see a band of colors emerge from white light. Then used another prism to recombine it back into white light.

Title: Conservation of momentum
Description: Momentum (p=mv) must be conserved in a closed system. First of the fundamental conservation laws.

Title: No spontaneous generation
Description: Devised a biological experiment with controls (first of its kind) to see if spoiled meat in a sealed flask would generate maggots. Answer: no.

Title: Reflecting telescopes
Description: Previous refracting telescopes suffered from chromatic abberation (which Newton studied in detail with prisms). New design used a curved mirror instead of a lens.

Title: Calculus
Description: Working out laws of gravity, Newton needed a new mathematical tool. Simultaneous discovery with Liebnitz, led to epic scientific conflict for centuries.

Title: Phosphorus
Description: Nine modern elements were known at the time (eg. gold) but their discoverers were unknown. Brand discovered Phosphorus in an attempt to create gold out of urine.

Title: Fossils
Description: Fossils first identified as petrified remnants of life. View eventually prevailed. Spectacular evidence of evolution.

Title: Double refraction
Description: Also known as birefringence, the phenomenon involves multiple paths of light going through a calcite prism. One of the paths is polarized. (TIL).

Title: Blood colors
Description: Observed different colors of blood. His work Tractatus de Corde first documented that dark red blood in veins turned brighter red from contact with air.

Title: Diabetes diagnosed
Description: May have been known by ancients that diabetic urine was sweet from all of the flies that accumulated.

Title: Saturn's four moons
Description: Huygens thought that the 6 known satellites (4 around Jupiter, Titan around Saturn and Moon around Earth) matched the 6 known planets, so that was that. Cassini proved him wrong.

Title: Mars distance
Description: Two millenium before, estimates of distance to Moon was established, but no other astronomical distances since. Cassini determined position of Mars as seen from Paris. Also determined size of solar system in general. Calculated Saturn orbit (farthest known planet) was at least 1.6e9 miles across

Title: Speed of light
Description: Estimated speed of light. Galileo tried to record speed of light, but failed. Roemer observed Jupiter's satellites from Paris Observatory, found eclipses were earlier at times of year when Earth was approaching Jupiter, and later when receding. Estimated c to be 3/4 of its actual value.

Title: Saturn's multiple rings
Description: Cassini observed a dark line separating inner and outer ring. Known as "cassini's division"

Title: Microorganisms
Description: Used small single lenses ground expertly to produce 200x magnification. Observed "animalcules" in pond water. Also first detected spermatazoa in semen.

Title: Southern stars
Description: First systematic observations of southern skies. Southern sky was never visible to Europeans. Halley traveled to St. Helena in south Atlantic, returned with a catalog of 341 southern stars.

Title: Light as wave
Description: Light: particle or wave controversy grew sharper. Newton couldn't see how light was a wave (there is nothing to wave), Huygens thought light traveled through an aether.

Title: Pressure cookers
Description: First useful application of steam. Tightly fitted lid increased boiling point of water to cook meat faster.

Title: Human kinetics
Description: Mechanical model for human kinetics. Modeled human bone and muscle as a system of levers, applying the same laws of physics to our body.

Title: Dodo extinct
Description: Dodo became first anthrogenic extinction. Mauritius had many species that evolved in isolation and were different from elsewhere. Dodo had no natural predators until the Dutch came and gradually killed them all.

Title: Plant sexuality
Description: Some plants shown to reproduce sexually, sexual plant organs, that plant pollen is equivalent to animal sperm. Previously, plants were assumed to be semi-alive (eg. in Genesis, they appear alongside dry land)

Title: Bacteria
Description: Continuing to rely on his excellent lenses, saw even smaller organisms than "animalcules", which in retrospect turned out to be bacteria.

Title: Earth size accurate
Description: Improvement over Eratosthenes' estimate based on distance of a star from zenith at different places using the help of telescopes. Estimate for radius was 3950 miles (actual 3,958.8)

Title: Complex numbers
Description: First used the complex plane to represent i=sqrt(-1).

Title: Trade winds mapped
Description: First world map showing consistent winds. Seasonal winds called monsoons come from the arabic word meaning "season". These and steady winds were never documented before. Halley hinted at sun-heated air but didn't understand reason for westward flow.

Title: Plant species classified
Description: Published a volume classifying 18600 different plant species, including a pretty good taxonomy.

Title: Laws of motion
Description: Since Kepler discovered eliptical orbits, many scientists tried to understand the underlying laws. Eventually Newton published Principia, widely considered greatest science book ever written. Included three laws of motion.

Title: Universal graviation
Description: Formulation of the force of gravity between any two bodies (that F=G m1 m2 / d^2) explained bodies in known universe.

Title: Non-spherical earth
Description: Earth shape suggested as oblate spheroid. When Richer traveled to Cayenne to determine Mars parallax, found pendelum beats slower there than in Paris. Newton suggested that this was due to difference in gravity at equator vs. at poles. This would mean earth would bulge.

Title: Plate glass
Description: Techniques for making glass without blowing. Clear glass was a luxury until in France, large sheets of glass were made for mirrors and windows, and went into widespread use.

Title: Improved animal classifications
Description: Classified animals logistically based on hooves, toes, and teeth.

Title: Calculating machines
Description: Built the Step Reckoner, a mechanical aid to calculation of trig and astronomical tables.

Title: Mortality tables
Description: He produced a life table showing the number of people surviving to any age from a cohort born the same year

Title: Miner's friend
Description: Miner's Friend invented to pump water out of flooded mines. Steam-powered air pump to help English coal mining, which was increasingly relied upon because of shortage of wood.

Title: Scientific ocean voyages
Description: First ocean voyage exclusively for science. Prior, voyages were taken for exploration, settlement or trade, with science as a side-effect. Halley's voyage measured magnetic declinations around the world, prepared first map of the world showing isodeclination, and accurate lat/long for ports.

Title: Gas volume temperature
Description: Discovery that volume of gas proportional to temperature. A step towards gas laws, but not quite precise enough measurements yet.

Title: Binary system
Description: First use of non-decimal bases (8, 12) as well as binary system.
